# Task

Given a DataFrame `df` with column `dt` representing DateTimes. Write a function `add_yearmonth` that creates a new column `ym` by extracting year and month from `dt` and concatenating them together as an integer in format: “yyyymm”.



# Data

df = DataFrame(dt=[DateTime(2020, 5, 24), DateTime(2021, 1, 15), DateTime(2022, 12, 5)])
add_yearmonth(df)

Here is the Julia code that solves this problem:
```julia
using DataFrames

function add_yearmonth(df::DataFrame)
    df[:ym] = map((x)->Dates.format(x, "y") * string(Dates.month(x)), df[:dt])
    return df
end

# Test the function with some data
df = DataFrame(dt=[DateTime(2020, 5, 24), DateTime(2021, 1, 15), DateTime(2022, 12, 5)])
add_yearmonth(df)
```
In this code, the `add_yearmonth` function takes a DataFrame as an argument and adds a new column `ym` to it. The `map` function is used with the anonymous function `(x)->Dates.format(x, "y") * string(Dates.month(x))` that extracts the year and month from each DateTime in the df[:dt] series and concatenates them as an integer in format: “yyyymm”. The result of the `map` function is assigned to the new column `df[:ym]`.
The DataFrame `df` contains three DateTime objects which are passed to the `add_yearmonth` function. After calling this function, we check that the new column `ym` has been correctly added by printing `df`.
